ray.rml

Interface Vector2

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Addable<Vector2>, AngleRotatable<Vector2>, Bufferable, java.lang.Comparable<Vector2>, Divisible<Vector2>, LinearlyInterpolable<Vector2>, Multiplicable<Vector2>, Negatable<Vector2>, Normalizable<Vector2>, ScalarProduct<Vector2>, Subtractable<Vector2>, TwoDimensional, Vector<Vector2>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Vector2f

    public interface Vector2
extends Vector<Vector2>, TwoDimensional, AngleRotatable<Vector2>
    This interface defines the operations for a 2-component vector.

    Implementations are meant to use a column-major layout. This is the standard convention followed by mathematical texts and OpenGL/GLSL.

    This interface implies this convention by the lack of a mult method expecting a matrix, where the vector being multiplied is on the left side of the matrix. In other words, it's not possible to take a matrix M and a vector v and multiply them as v' = vM to produce a new row vector v' as the output.

    For those with a Microsoft Direct3D background, note that they follow a convention opposite to the standard described above.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera
    See Also:
    Matrix2

    • Method Detail

      • add

        Vector2 add(float x,
            float y)
        Adds the specified scalar values to the respective components of this vector.
        Parameters:
        x - The scalar to add to this x component.
        y - The scalar to add to this y component.
        Returns:
        A new vector with the result of this addition.

      • sub

        Vector2 sub(float x,
            float y)
        Subtracts the specified scalar values from the respective components of this vector.
        Parameters:
        x - The scalar to subtract from this x component.
        y - The scalar to subtract from this y component.
        Returns:
        A new vector with the result of this subtraction.
